Exporting room data 
to Excel

GETTING STARTED WITH FORMIT | 383
Getting Started with FormIt
Autodesk’s FormIt application is architectural modeling software that enables architects 
to sketch, collaborate, analyze, and revise early-stage design concepts. FormIt began as an 
iPad-only application but is now also available as a full desktop application. FormIt has the 
capability to create conceptual design models and output presentation-quality images. From 
inception, FormIt’s mission has been to eliminate the “throw-away” design model by enabling 
the transition from a free-ﬂowing concept design phase model to a design development and 
documentation model in Revit. This capability has grown in Revit 2018. We will explore a few 
of the interoperability-focused workﬂows between FormIt and Revit in this section. FormIt is 
available on Windows, installed side by side with Revit (http://formit360.autodesk.com). 
In Figure 10.30, you can see examples of conceptual FormIt models.
Figure 10.30 
FormIt models 
shown with 
two diﬀerent 
rendering styles
FormIt is intended for architectural designers in the conceptual design phase of a project. 
FormIt ﬁts between the loose push-and-pull modeling environment reminiscent of SketchUp 
and the powerful constraints of Autodesk Revit. FormIt introduces BIM concepts early in the 
design process and maintains intelligent model elements downstream to Revit.
Conceptual design is an important phase of any project where general massing crucially 
informs building area, solar impact, and whole-building energy analysis. These early decisions 
and the compelling presentation imagery shared with stakeholders are essential to winning proj-
ect work. Too often schematic design models are “thrown away” when the work is won and 
project documentation begins. FormIt exists to end the throw-away model by smoothly con-
necting models to Revit.
Understanding the FormIt UI
Before you get started with massing and model building exercises, let’s take a quick look at the 
application and the basic interactions such as camera navigation and selection. The FormIt user 
interface is designed to have common tools you need right at your ﬁngertips for quick decision-
making. The overall UI looks like Figure 10.31.

384 | CHAPTER 10 CONCEPTUAL DESIGN 
Navigation
First, the FormIt mouse commands work very much like the Revit commands. Zooming, pan-
ning, orbiting, and swiveling use the same mouse movements as Revit. Just like with Revit, 
you can also access these tools from a menu command. They are located on the right side of the 
screen (see Figure 10.32).
Figure 10.31 
Te FormIt UI
Figure 10.32 
FormIt naviga-
tion tools
In this screen, creation and editing tools appear across the top. Here you can create and 
manipulate and perform selections and measurements. Down the right side of Figure 10.31 are 
the navigation tools. Before we get into form creation and manipulation, let’s take a quick look at 
how to move around within the model.

GETTING STARTED WITH FORMIT | 385
To change your view angle, you can use the middle mouse button, similar to Revit. Different 
from Revit, FormIt does not have a ViewCube but instead has three tools in the upper-right 
corner of the UI to help with model orientation (Figure 10.33). These tools are referred to as view 
modes. Perspective View, Top View, and Fly-Through are different modes to review your model.
Figure 10.33 
FormIt view modes
FormIt is always operating from a 3D viewpoint. Currently there are no 2D views that cut 
geometry like plans or sections in Revit. Primarily, you will be modeling in a 3D perspective 
camera orientation.
When you select the Top View tool, you enter a plan view, but it’s important to note that this 
view is similar to a site plan—you are above the entire model, looking down from the sky.
The other icon associated with Top View and Perspective View is the Fly-Through mode, 
which is a fun ﬁrst-person-style walk-through. You can move through your model with WASD 
keyboard controls and hover (like with a jet-pack) using the spacebar. You can also take steps up 
and down with Q and E. This is helpful for setting up custom scenes, which we’ll discuss later.
Modeling
Now that you know the basics of navigation, we’ll explore the essential selection and modeling 
interactions tools. The Action bar at the top of the screen has several tools (Figure 10.34).
 
◆
The Pencil tool has a few sketch tools in the ﬂyout menu that allow you to draw lines, arcs, 
and shapes.
 
◆
The Line tool (L) allows you to sketch in lines on the ground plane and “up” into the z-axis 
as well.
 
◆
The Rectangle (R) tool is essential, and you’ll use it heavily when you get to modeling.
 
◆
The Arc (A), Spline (S), and Circle (C) tools are exactly what they sound like, allowing you 
to draw those shapes.
Figure 10.34 
FormIt modeling tools

386 | CHAPTER 10 CONCEPTUAL DESIGN 
Please try all of these different drawing tools out in the drawing view, called the Canvas 
in FormIt. To place a point, click anywhere in the canvas. The default drawing mode is using 
the Line tool, and this will place your ﬁrst point. To place the second point, click in the canvas 
again. The two points will automatically connect with a line.
You’ll notice an editable dimension appear as you’re drawing lines. You can either click 
the dimension box or press the Tab key to bring up a small dialog box where you can input a 
speciﬁc dimension (Figure 10.35).
Figure 10.35 
Drawing to an exact 
dimension
While you’re placing points in the sketch tools, you’ll see red, green, and blue axis lines 
appear on the canvas. These are guides that correspond to the x-, y-, and z-axes of your model. 
When they appear, hold down the Shift key to “lock” your next point onto that axis. This 
enables you to draw perfectly parallel and perpendicular lines in the 3D canvas.
If you start drawing lines off the cardinal XYZ grid, then you’ll begin seeing purple guides 
appear—these represent axes parallel and perpendicular to the custom angles you’ve drawn. As 
you’re drawing lines, you’ll notice small, colorful snap icons appear. These represent the basic 
snaps you are familiar with from Revit.
 
◆
Red square icons indicate “endpoint.”
 
◆
Green circle icons indicate “on edge.”
 
◆
Red triangle icons indicate “midpoint.”
 
◆
Blue diamond icons indicate “on face.”
When you have drawn a “closed loop” of lines, a geometric face will automatically be created. 
You’ll still be in the sketch tool, so you can continue sketching from the last placed point. Once 
you are done sketching, you can hit the Esc key to stay in the sketch tool (your next mouse click 
will start your next line), or you can hit the spacebar to clear the sketch tool and start selecting 
other geometry.
At its heart, FormIt is a fun, fast, push-pull modeler. There are a few tricks to master in order 
to be a push-pull pro. Note that FormIt calls the push-pull tool Drag Face.
Select a face by clicking one. If you already have a face drawn (from the previous sketching 
exploration), then go ahead and select it. If you don’t, then draw a Rectangle and then hit Esc a 
few times to clear the sketch tool.

GETTING STARTED WITH FORMIT | 387
Once you select a face, you are automatically put into the push-pull tool. You have to click 
only once (on the face or on an endpoint of the face) to start the drag face operation. Then 
you are free to move your mouse to the desired location and click again to end the drag face. 
Figure 10.36 demonstrates the Drag Face tool.
Figure 10.36 
Manipulating 
geometry with the 
Drag Face tool
When you start a drag face, you’ll see a blue axis line appear. This indicates the orthogonal 
(or normal) direction you can pull the face. Essentially you’re already locked onto an axis in 
drag face, so your mouse can wander all over the canvas and snap to any other point or face. 
This allows you to align your drag face with any other element in the model.
Note that you can select more than one face at a time (by holding down the Shift key when 
you click to select similar to Revit). Then you can drag more than one face at a time.
One essential technique to practice is splitting a face, which combines sketch tools with the 
Drag Face tool. Choose the Line tool (L) and split a face by drawing a line from the midpoint 
of one edge to the midpoint of another edge on the face. This will create two faces where there 
used to be one—you’ve split a face! When you select one of the faces, you can push it in or out of 
the plane of the face. Figure 10.37 shows the results of the Split Face tool.
Figure 10.37 
Manipulating 
geometry with the 
Drag Face tool

388 | CHAPTER 10 CONCEPTUAL DESIGN 
Selecting Elements
FormIt has a hover highlight tool that indicates what you are about to select. This gets you 
started, but of course there are selection tricks that you’ll want to master too. Here’s a list of a 
few of the tools you’ll want to get to know in order to use FormIt more ﬂuidly.
 
◆
Click to select a face.
 
◆
Click to also select edges (click the desired edge).
 
◆
Click to select vertices (endpoints of faces and faces).
 
◆
Click to select groups. You’ll create groups later in this chapter.
 
◆
Double-click to select everything that is connected by a line or face. If you place a cube in 
the model, you can click faces and edges. If you double-click the cube, you select the entire 
cube. If you’ve created a more complex shape than a cube, then you can still double-click to 
select all of it at once.
 
◆
Double-click will select less important elements such as imported images and imported 
satellite images.
 
◆
Double-click is also an essential shortcut to move into group edit mode.
Finally, for multiselection, you’ll start from the upper-left corner of your canvas and drag 
your mouse across the elements in your canvas to the lower-right corner of the canvas. You’ll see 
a red rectangle appear to indicate the “window” of the canvas that you’ve selected. You can ﬁlter 
your selection with the Select tool in the Select + Filter ﬂyout (Figure 10.38).
Figure 10.38 
Filtering a 
selection
Understanding Context Menus
FormIt has a minimal user interface to keep the focus of the interactions in the modeling canvas. 
There are a number of useful tools that are hidden in context menus accessed after selecting 
speciﬁc geometry. To access the context menu, you’ll have to select the thing you want to edit 
and right-click the mouse. You will see a circular context menu appear with the tools available 
related to that FormIt element (Figure 10.39). We won’t deﬁne all the tools in the FormIt context 
menus. That’s what the FormIt Help documentation is for!

GETTING STARTED WITH FORMIT | 389
Using Groups
Before moving on to a massing and modeling exercise, we have to pause and discuss groups. 
Groups are fundamental to successful modeling in FormIt and are also the vehicle to translate 
geometry to Revit. Groups are the key to creating distinct building components. Groups also 
allow you to separate geometry so elements don’t automatically combine. To illustrate this, let’s 
do a simple exercise without groups.
1. Place a cube from the 3D Primitives toolbar on to the canvas (Figure 10.40).
Figure 10.39 
FormIt context 
menus
Figure 10.40 
Placing a prim-
itive form
2. Start the Rectangle (R) sketch tool and draw a rectangle, making sure the edge of the rect-
angle overlaps with the edge of the cube.
3. When you’re done with the Rectangle tool, hit Esc on your keyboard to clear the tool.
4. Select the face of the rectangle and pull it up to make a solid. Finally, double-click the 
resulting geometry.
You should see that your cube and your extruded rectangle are essentially joined together 
and are now a single element, as in Figure 10.41. This is what happens when elements are cre-
ated outside of a group.

390 | CHAPTER 10 CONCEPTUAL DESIGN 
Let’s try a similar exercise but this time using groups.
1. Place a cube from the 3D Primitives toolbar.
2. Don’t hit the Esc key to keep the cube in selection, or double-click to select the cube again.
3. With the cube selected, right-click and choose the Create Group command, or press  
the G keyboard shortcut. The cube should have a dashed line around it and a stipple 
pattern on it.
4. Click in a blank part of the canvas to unselect, or hit Esc to clear the selection.
5. Draw a rectangle (R) as you did before, with one side connected to the cube.
6. Select the resulting face, and drag it up to create a solid.
7. Double-click to select the extruded rectangle. Add the group to the selection by holding 
down Ctrl and select the group.
The result will look like Figure 10.42. While similar to the other workﬂow, the key difference 
is that the elements will now move independently. They are not automatically joined.
Groups are also the method for creating parent-child relationships such that a change to one 
instance ripples through the model and updates all of the related groups. In Revit terminology, 
they are similar to families.
Figure 10.41 
Joined geom-
etry in FormIt

GETTING STARTED WITH FORMIT | 391
There are a handful of group-speciﬁc commands on the context menu when you have a 
group selected. Click a group to select it and then right-click. We’ll review these icons in coun-
terclockwise order from the top of the circular context menu shown in Figure 10.43.
Figure 10.42 
Unjoined 
geometry 
inside a group
Figure 10.43 
Te Group 
context menu

392 | CHAPTER 10 CONCEPTUAL DESIGN 
Starting at the top of the circle and moving counterclockwise, the tools are as follows:
Create Group (G)  You can create a group around a group, which is essentially what hap-
pens when you make nested groups.
Edit Group (E)  This is another way to enter into Edit Group mode. The double-click is more 
direct, but you can also select this icon, or you can select a group and type E for the keyboard 
shortcut.
Make Unique (MU)  This allows you to sever the relationship of this group from the other 
instances of the group. Now you can make changes to this particular group without affecting 
other groups.
Ungroup (U)  This tool explodes the group currently selected, leaving you with the indi-
vidual components. No geometry is deleted in this action.
Ungroup All (UA)  This tool is a bit more destructive, but it’s also a big time-saver if you 
have many nested groups. Ungroup All will ungroup everything below the currently 
edited group.
As we mentioned, groups are roughly equivalent to the concept of families in Revit. To that 
end, FormIt provides a way to categorize groups so that when they are imported to Revit, they will 
become families of a speciﬁed category. The list of categories is short but can be helpful. By default, 
groups are categorized as Mass. To modify the category, double-click to edit a group and then look 
in the Properties palette; you will see a category drop-down (Figure 10.44). Here you can choose 
from Casework, Entourage, Furniture, Furniture Systems, Generic Models, Parking, Site, and 
Specialty Equipment. We’ll talk more about techniques for importing to Revit later in this chapter.
Figure 10.44 
Modifying 
a group’s 
category
Using FormIt for Massing
You have now practiced a few of the basic interactions of FormIt, had a chance to explore the 
interface, and drawn a few shapes. Let’s go through the most basic workﬂow in FormIt. You are 
going to model a simple mass and migrate that content to Revit.
Like Revit, FormIt is linked to Autodesk’s A360 platform. The online workspace allows for 
interoperability between many of Autodesk’s applications. To begin the exercise, you ﬁrst need 
to be signed in to A360. Select the avatar icon in the upper right of the FormIt tool (Figure 10.45) 
to sign in. If you don’t have an account, you can create one from here. This is an essential step as 
the A360 platform will convert FormIt content to Revit content.

GETTING STARTED WITH FORMIT | 393
1. Let’s make sure you’re starting the exercise with a clean canvas. Start a New FormIt 
project (Ctrl+N) from the File drop-down (Figure 10.46) and choose New.

For the next exercise, we’re going to look at how FormIt deals with shade and shadow. Not only

Selecting this tool will activate the Shadows dialog box. Selecting the Shadows check box at

to choose the time of day and day of year to explore the shadow conditions you desire to visual-

Converting FormIt to Revit
As we mentioned at the beginning of this section, FormIt is designed to be a conceptual model-
ing tool with which you can easily migrate models to Revit. However, before migrating FormIt 
to Revit, let’s take a moment and do a “preﬂight check” of the FormIt geometry to ensure that it 
will import as expected. FormIt has a few model diagnostic features to help see any issues that 
may impact a successful conversion of your design geometry to Revit (or 3D printing). This is 
referred to as checking to see whether the model is “water tight.” What FormIt looks for is gaps 
in the geometry that would work in FormIt but not transfer properly to Revit.
To perform this check, look in the Visual Styles panel, go to the Diagnostics tab, and enable 
Watertight Issues and Back Faces (Figure 10.54). Any oddities in your model, such as nonsolids, 
stray edges, shared edges, inside out faces, and so on, will show up as red in this view. Those 
geometries will need to be resolved before you can successfully move the model to Revit.
Figure 10.54 
Checking the 
FormIt model 
geometry prior 
to moving the 
content to Revit
If you do see red highlighting geometric ﬁdelity issues, you can use the following to address 
them: use the Cover (CV) tool to heal missing faces on solids; delete stray edges (edges that 
do not enclose a region) or select inside-out faces, right-click, and choose Reverse Faces (FF). 
When your model is clean, save your ﬁle locally (Ctrl+S). This will create an AXM ﬁle that you’ll 
import to Revit. We used the c10_01_MassExample.axm ﬁle from earlier in this section.
Importing to Revit
To import the ﬁle into Revit, open Autodesk Revit 2018 and start a new ﬁle with the Architectural 
template. You can either stay in plan view or open the default 3D view. Next, select the Import 
FormIt To RVT tool from the FormIt Converter panel on the Add-Ins tab (Figure 10.55). If you 
don’t have this tab visible, your version of Revit is likely out of date, and we recommend you run 
the updates from the Autodesk Application Manager in the system tray.
Figure 10.55 
Importing FormIt ﬁles 
to Revit

398 | CHAPTER 10 CONCEPTUAL DESIGN 
Click the drop-down menu and click the Import FormIt To Revit button. Navigate to the 
AXM ﬁle you just saved from the FormIt export and select it. Revit will start the import process, 
which may take a few moments depending on how many groups you had in your FormIt sketch. 
If there are any errors in the import process, Revit will report the name of the FormIt group that 
it had trouble importing.
The FormIt geometry is now imported into Revit, and you should see 3D massing geom-
etry in your view (Figure 10.56). If you don’t see them, you may need to visit the Visibility And 
Graphics dialog (VG) and enable the Mass category. You can ﬁnd the imported Revit model on 
this book’s companion web page. The model is called c10_01_MassExample.rvt.
Figure 10.56 
Imported FormIt 
geometry in Revit
FormIt levels and their custom names have been imported to Revit also. If you open an eleva-
tion or section view, you will see your FormIt levels represented. You can create Revit ﬂoor 
plans from these levels by navigating to the View tab, choosing Floor Plans, and selecting all of 
the imported levels.
The FormIt levels automatically created mass ﬂoors cutting through your mass geometry. 
Revit allows you to attached Revit system families to mass objects using the Wall By Face, 

ADVANCED MODELING IN FORMIT | 399
Curtain System By Face, and Roof By Face tools located on the Massing & Site tab in the Model 
By Face panel. By associating geometry with the mass, you can continue to work in FormIt to 
further reﬁne your design. When you re-import your model content into Revit, it will move any 
Revit system families to address any changes in the newly imported model.
Another thing that imports into Revit beyond the geometry is the location you speciﬁed as 
well as the time of day and day of year. The geometry is imported relative to the 0,0,0 point of 
the x-, y-, and z-axes in FormIt.
You can continue to import any FormIt geometry into Revit as the FormIt model  
evolves. You can also export Revit geometry back to your FormIt model as SAT ﬁles (Revit  
menu icon ➢ Export ➢ CAD Formats ➢ ACIS (SAT)). The ﬁnished ﬁle for this example is  
c10_02_MassExample_Finished.rvt.

Moving from a Mass to a Model
The Shell Solid(s) tool in FormIt is the fastest way to go from a conceptual massing study to a 
conceptual design model with interior volumes. Luckily, this powerful tool is also easy to use. 
To use the shell tool to create a corner window condition, follow these steps:
1. Start a new FormIt ﬁle and place a cube from the 3D Primitives drop-down on the canvas.
2. Click the Advanced Geometry toolbar (the cube with the lightning bolt) and choose the 
Shell Solid(s) tool (Figure 10.58).
Figure 10.58 
Selecting the 
shell tool from

Geometry 
toolbar
Figure 10.59

shelled mass
3. You’ll be presented with a dialog box to enter the thickness of the shell. Note a negative 
value indicates the offset will be in from the outside face of the mass. Set the value to -1′ 
(30 cm). You’ll mimic a 1′-0″ thick wall enclosure. Click OK to close the dialog box.
4. Select the top face of the cube and press Enter. This will remove the top face so you can 
see into your shelled mass. Since you clicked only the top face, it disappears to reveal  
the inside of a volume that has wall thickness and a ﬂoor (Figure 10.59). You can also 
download this completed ﬁle from the book’s companion web page. The ﬁle is called 
c10_02_ModelExample_ShelledMass.axm.

1200 cm). Click Esc to exit the Rectangle tool. Make a similar window on the adjoining 
side of the shell so it forms a single window on the corner. Finally, select the rectangle 
(once on both sides) and push the rectangle to delete the shape to form an opening.

model, c10_03_ModelExample_WindownOpening.axm.

you give it these shapes, FormIt will automatically create complex geometry for you.
a. Zoom into one of the corners of your window opening.

should be 2′ wide by 2″ thick (60 cm × 5 cm), as in Figure 10.61.

1. To add materiality to objects, you ﬁrst need to add materials to the model. Select the

material onto one face of the geometry at a time.

faces of the object at once, just like double-clicking to select a solid. Click off in space to

apply materials to all the faces of a group. Finally, we’ll override the glass to be transparent.

list. Note that the thumbnail has a checkerboard pattern indicating that the material has 
some transparency. Click the thumbnail, and click the glass group to paint it. Click Esc to 
exit the paintbrush tool, and hit Esc again to exit the window frame group. Press Ctrl+S to 
save you work. The ﬁnal model should look like Figure 10.67.

 Chapter  11 
 Working with Phasing, Groups, 
and Design Options   
 Projects will progress through various stages during design and construction. As a result, it is 
sometimes necessary to distinguish the element of time within your project: when something is 
created, if it is demolished, and what it will look like when the project is complete. Beyond just 
phasing, design is also about maintaining relationships between repetitive elements. Sometimes 
this repetitive element can be a single component in your project, such as a light or a piece of 
furniture. But it can also be an entire collection of elements, such as a typical room in a hotel or 
hospital. 
 Another fundamental aspect of design is the iteration of options. You have to be able to see 
many ideas simultaneously and in context with other ideas. The client and contractor need to 
see options and alternates. It is important that these options not be fully independent, separate 
ﬁ les so that the results can be analyzed and compared. 
 This chapter focuses on these three concepts: time, repetition, and iteration of options. 
In Autodesk ® Revit ® software, they’re addressed with phasing, groups, and design options, 
respectively. 
 In this chapter, you will learn to 
 
◆
 Use the Phasing tools to create, demolish, and propose a new design 
 
◆
Understand and use groups 
 
◆
Create and use design options 
 Using Phasing 
Phasing is the software’s method of allowing you to add the element of time to objects in your 
project. It is easy to think of an architectural design in terms of what something is, where some-
thing is, and how it will be assembled. Phasing adds the dimension of  when something is, which 
is incredibly useful and powerful. 
 Phases are most useful for doing the kinds of tasks that require you to show when elements 
are being introduced into your design, such as showing demolition and new construction in an 
existing building or showing different drawing packages as examples. But a few words of cau-
tion and clariﬁ cation: we do not recommend using extensive phasing to simulate construction 
sequencing, which is referred to as 4D. It might seem like a great idea at ﬁ rst, but ultimately it 
will degrade the performance of your model and lead to confusion across your project team. 
Certiﬁcation
Objective
Mastering Autodesk® Revit® 2018 
By Lance Kirby, Eddy Krygiel and Marcus Kim 
Copyright © 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc., Indianapolis, Indiana 

408 | CHAPTER 11 WORKING WITH PHASING, GROUPS, AND DESIGN OPTIONS  
There is a far more efﬁcient method of simulating construction sequences that allows model 
elements to be scheduled, viewed, and even color-coded based on the sequence value that you 
deﬁne: project parameters.
By using project parameters, you are able to create and assign an instance parameter value to 
everything in your project that you would want to assign a construction sequence, as shown in 
Figure 11.1.
Figure 11.1 
Creating a con-
struction sequence 
instance parameter 
for project geometry
Once you have created this instance parameter, you will be able to create view ﬁlters that over-
ride the default display style of an object based on the parameter value, as shown in Figure 11.2. 
Each construction week value is assigned to a ﬁlter rule.
Figure 11.2 
Developing ﬁlters by 
parameter

USING PHASING | 409
Combined with visibility and graphic overrides, you are able to create a ﬁlter that modiﬁes 
the graphics based on a parameter, as shown in Figure 11.3.
Figure 11.3 
Applying ﬁlters to 
graphic override 
settings
As a result of applying parameter-based ﬁlters, you will be able to modify the graphics of 
a view to illustrate some metadata about the objects in a far more ﬂexible and predictable way 
than with the phasing functionality, as shown in Figure 11.4. Another beneﬁt is that this technique 
is not limited to views of geometry. View ﬁlters can be applied to any view, including schedules, 
which will allow you to group and ﬁlter schedules based on your unique project parameter.
Figure 11.4 
Using parameters and 
view ﬁlters to override 
graphics
Now that you understand a better way to create sequencing in Revit using parameters and 
ﬁlters, we will discuss how phasing is best used. To work along with the steps in the following 
section, download and open the ﬁle c11-Phases-Start.rvt from this book’s web page at  
www.sybex.com/go/masteringrevit2018.
What Can You Phase?
All modeled elements in Revit have two parameters associated with phasing: Phase Created 
and Phase Demolished. When you place geometry in a view, the Phase Created property by 
default is the phase assigned to that view. For example, if your view is set to Phase Existing, all 
elements you place in that view will automatically be assigned to the Existing phase. After an 
element is placed in the project, the phase can always be changed in the Properties palette, as 
shown in Figure 11.5.

410 | CHAPTER 11 WORKING WITH PHASING, GROUPS, AND DESIGN OPTIONS  
Figure 11.5 
Changing the phase  
of geometry (near  
the bottom of the  
dialog box)
Rooms also have phasing properties, but there is an important difference: the Phase property 
of a room cannot be changed after it is placed. As shown in Figure 11.6, the phase is shown in 
the Properties palette, but it is read only. If you want to change the phase of a room, you will 
need to delete and re-create the room in a view that is assigned the desired phase. You also 
might ﬁnd it faster to press Ctrl+X to cut the rooms from one view and then press Ctrl+V to paste 
them into a view that has been set to the desired phase.
Figure 11.6 
Te Phase of a room 
may not be changed 
after placement.

USING PHASING | 411
The phase of an element when initially placed is often confusing to a new user, but it is 
quite simple: the phase of the view that you are placing the element into determines the ele-
ment’s phase, as shown in Figure 11.7. This is more critical for rooms than for building elements 
because the phase of a building element can be changed after placement. But there may be occa-
sions when you are placing many elements that you intend to be in a particular phase, and you 
will want to create a view with that phase active. This will allow you to place elements in that 
view and not worry about changing their phase later. Changing the name of the view to match 
its current phase is a good technique for organizing multiple phased views.
Figure 11.7 
Changing the phase 
of a view
Implementing Phase Settings
Applying the notion of time to your project may seem complicated, but it is actually quite simple 
to implement. You just need to understand three basic aspects about the settings related to 
phasing.
 
◆
What are the major phases of your project?
 
◆
How will you use the phasing properties to ﬁlter views within your project 
documentation?
 
◆
What is the graphic convention to convey an object’s phase?
These aspects are expressed in the three tabs of the Phasing dialog box. On the Manage 
tab of the ribbon, click the Phasing button to open the Phasing dialog box, shown in  
Figure 11.8.

412 | CHAPTER 11 WORKING WITH PHASING, GROUPS, AND DESIGN OPTIONS  
Figure 11.8 
Te Phasing 
dialog box
Applying Project Phases
In the most common of phased projects, you will have views to illustrate Existing, Demolition, 
and New Construction conditions. On more complex projects, you might have several stages 
of new construction as you build out larger facilities. This dialog box shows only Existing and 
New Construction, so new users may mistakenly create a new phase for Demolition. As we will 
demonstrate later, demolished elements are represented with phase ﬁlters, not as a dedicated 
project phase.
So, when do you need to create more than the phases shown by default? As one example, 
think of a staged construction project that will happen in two new phases. In this scenario, 
you are designing with a start time for the building shell followed by another phase for interi-
ors, allowing the owner to split funding for the project into two budgets. In the ﬁrst phase, the 
building core and shell are built. In the second phase, interior construction occurs. Your ﬁrst 
phase is labeled Shell And Core. Your other phase is labeled Interiors. This phasing also gives a 
contractor who is familiar with Revit the ability to use the model to see what needs to be built 
and when. Depending on how your model is created, the contractor can even do cost estimates 
by phase.
In the Project Phases tab of the Phasing dialog box, create the two phases as we just described 
(Figure 11.9). You can simply rename the New Construction phase Shell and Core. Click the 
Insert After button to create an additional project phase and then rename it Interiors. We will 
use these in a sample exercise in a moment. When you are creating phases, you might notice 
there is no Delete button. You cannot delete a phase once you have added it, because you do not 
want to delete any geometry placed on any phase by deleting just that phase. Should your plan-
ning process change and you want to eliminate a phase, you can merge two phases using either 
of the Combine With buttons on the right, without the fear of losing model objects associated 
with those retired phases.

USING PHASING | 413
Figure 11.9 
Creating additional 
project phases
Click OK to accept the changes and close the Phasing dialog box; then activate the Level 1 
ﬂoor plan. Once you have created these additional project phases, pick any project geometry and 
look at its instance parameters. You will notice in the Properties palette that it can be assigned to 
any one of these three phases, as shown in Figure 11.10.
Figure 11.10 
Assigning available 
phases
Applying Phase Filters
Return to the Manage tab in the ribbon and once again click the Phasing tool. The middle tab in 
the Phasing dialog box is Phase Filters (Figure 11.11). Seven predeﬁned phase ﬁlters are listed.

414 | CHAPTER 11 WORKING WITH PHASING, GROUPS, AND DESIGN OPTIONS  
Figure 11.11 
Te Phase Filters tab 
with seven predeﬁned 
phase ﬁlters
Do not be concerned if the ﬁlter names seem a bit cryptic at ﬁrst. What is really important are 
the four graphic conditions that can be overridden: New, Existing, Demolished, and Temporary. 
Let’s take a moment to explore how these graphic conditions are applied to a virtually unlim-
ited number of user-deﬁned project phases. Any object you place into a project has certain states 
relative to any particular phase. In other words, you might ask the following questions about a 
model element:
 
◆
Was it created in the current phase? This is new.
 
◆
Was it created in a previous phase? This is existing.
 
◆
Was it created in a previous phase and demolished in the current phase? This is demolished.
 
◆
Is the object created and demolished in the same phase? This is temporary.
As you can see, phase ﬁlters are relative settings. That is, the ﬁlters are relative to the phasing 
properties of the object and the phase of the view in which the object is displayed. Also realize 
that although phases are applied to elements, phase ﬁlters are applied only to views.
Now let’s explore the predeﬁned ways a phase ﬁlter can be applied. Select any of the drop-
down menus, as shown in Figure 11.12. You will notice that the phase ﬁlter can override the 
graphics in one of three ways.
By Category  The object can be shown by its category settings or not overridden. It will be 
displayed in the project just as it does by default.
Overridden  This means you can deﬁne a graphic override for that object. We will get into 
the graphic overrides in a moment.
Not Displayed  The object is hidden in the view. You should make sure you differentiate 
this from the object’s existence, as it will continue to interact with other components, visible 
or not.

USING PHASING | 415
Once you understand how each of the phase ﬁlters displays objects, phases can begin to 
make sense. For example, the Show Complete phase ﬁlter shows New and Existing elements 
By Category. But Demolished and Temporary elements are not displayed at all. Use this setting 
when you want to show the model in a ﬁnished condition. Another example is to use the Show 
New phase ﬁlter in a schedule such as in a door schedule. The Show New ﬁlter will include only 
those doors that are assigned to the phase that is also assigned to the schedule. The schedule 
will not list any existing doors or doors that were demolished.
If there is any remaining confusion, it likely involves the naming convention of Show 
Previous + Demo. A better name might be Show Existing + Demolition, but Existing is a bit 
misleading because this setting is showing the previous phase, which is not necessarily exist-
ing elements. They might be temporary elements that need to be demolished. Therefore, Show 
Previous makes more sense.
Using Graphic Overrides
The Graphic Overrides tab is the ﬁnal tab in the Phasing dialog box (Figure 11.13). This dialog 
box relates to the Overridden assignment of the previous tab.
Figure 11.12 
Setting a ﬁlter override
Figure 11.13 
Te Graphic

416 | CHAPTER 11 WORKING WITH PHASING, GROUPS, AND DESIGN OPTIONS  
This tab allows you to override geometry in a few areas: the Lines and Patterns character-
istics of Projection/Surface and Cut (which refers to the cut proﬁle of objects). You also have 
the option to just halftone the element. Finally, you can assign a unique Material setting when 
rendering. Although this ability is helpful for rendering with phase information, it can also 
be useful for rendering everything to a matte material, something we discuss in Chapter 12, 
“Visualization.” As it is, phasing can show you where you are (new construction) and where you 
are coming from (existing) but not where you are going (future).

can simply click model elements in the active view to set their Phase Demolished property to the 
phase of the view. It has even been suggested to Autodesk to include a hammering sound eﬀect 
to this tool!

Using the View Phase
Now that we have discussed the phasing properties of geometry, we will cover the phase prop-
erties of the views. Starting with the 3D view from the previous example, examine the view 
properties in the Properties palette, provided there are no model elements selected (Figure 11.20). 
We have collapsed some of the property groups at the top to show the Phasing properties at the 
bottom of the list.
Figure 11.20

420 | CHAPTER 11 WORKING WITH PHASING, GROUPS, AND DESIGN OPTIONS  
Remember that all the graphic overrides and ﬁlters for phasing are relative to the phase that 
is assigned to geometry or a view. By default, the New Construction phase is assigned to new 
views created in your project. This phase assignment can be changed at any time from the 
Properties palette. The phase property can also be assigned to a view template for easier man-
agement of this parameter.
The next important step is to apply the most appropriate phase ﬁlter. To illustrate how a 
phase ﬁlter changes the way objects are displayed in a view, you will step through several ﬁlters 
in the following exercises.
The default phase ﬁlter is Show All (Figure 11.21). This ﬁlter will show all the model elements 
relative to the phase assigned to the view and will override their graphics based on their Phase 
Created and Phase Demolished parameters. It also gives you a sense of all the elements as they 
exist in time.
Figure 11.21

ﬁlter for the New 
Construction phase
Green
Red
Blue
Although this is great for 3D views, where every phase has a distinct color, it is also useful 
for working in a plan, elevation, or section. To turn this graphic visibility on, activate the Level 1  
ﬂoor plan from the Project Browser and change the Graphic Display setting to Shaded or 
Consistent Colors. You will be able to clearly distinguish between objects in different phases, as 
shown in Figure 11.22.
Now let’s start moving through each of the phase ﬁlters. An important note: rather than mov-
ing through the various phase ﬁlters from top to bottom, we’ll move through time by changing 
the Phase parameter.
Return to the 3D view and keep Phase Filter set to Show All, but change Phase to Existing 
(Figure 11.23). This will show only the objects created in the Existing phase—and their graph-
ics are not overridden. The two walls that were assigned to the New Construction phase are not 
shown in the view because Revit does not provide a way to see future construction beyond the 
phase assigned to the view. Unfortunately, creating a future phase requires adding view-speciﬁc 
2D line work apart from the Phases tool.
Set the phase of the view back to New Construction and set the phase ﬁlter to Show Previous +

Construction phase.

Phasing with Linked Models
If you are working on larger-scale projects, you will want to keep some additional factors in mind 
when using phasing. To control phasing between linked models (which could be linked architectural 
models or consultant models), make sure your phase names are identical. If one model has “Existing +  
Demo” and the other team has “existing+demo,” the linked models will see those as diﬀerent phases. 
Remember, consistency is the key.
Moving forward in time, let’s now show only the elements in the New Construction  
phase. Set the phase ﬁlter to Show New and only one wall will be displayed, as shown in 
Figure 11.30.
Now comes the ﬁnal phase ﬁlter setting, Show Complete (Figure 11.31). This shows only the 
existing elements that were not demolished in previous phases up to the phase assigned to the 
view. Elements that are demolished in any phase are not displayed, and neither existing nor new 
elements are overridden. This phase ﬁlter is most often used for camera views where a render-
ing of the ﬁnished conditions may need to be generated without any sort of graphic overrides.

CREATING AND USING GROUPS | 425
Creating and Using Groups
It is easy to think of groups as functionally similar to blocks in Autodesk® AutoCAD® software 
or cells in Bentley MicroStation, but groups can be much more. They are great at maintaining 
repetition within your project, but there are some major differences.
 
◆
Creating groups is quite easy. And whether it is a 2D or 3D group, the insertion point for 
the group is easily deﬁned and modiﬁed. The same cannot be said of simple 2D blocks in 
other applications.
 
◆
Updating groups is a breeze. It is easy and intuitive to modify a group after it has been 
created. Practically anyone on your team can do it, which means that design workﬂow  
will not bottleneck in your project team.
 
◆
Copying groups throughout your project is also a breeze. Groups can be copied across dif-
ferent levels, rotated, and handle other modiﬁcations. We cover groups in more detail later 
in this chapter.
There are a few good practices that you will want to keep in mind when using groups. But 
they are so straightforward that you will wonder how you have ever worked without them.
Creating Groups
You can create two kinds of groups in Revit. One kind is just for geometry, called model groups. 
The other is just for view-speciﬁc content such as text, tags, dimensions, and so on, and are 
called detail groups. You can create one kind of group or the other explicitly. If you try to create 
a group with both model and detail elements, Revit is smart enough to create a separate detail 
group that is associated with the model group.
To demonstrate this, download and open the ﬁle c11-Groups-Start.rvt or  
c11-Groups-Start-Metric.rvt from this book’s web page. Activate the Level 1 ﬂoor  
plan and you will see four walls with dimensions, as shown in Figure 11.32.
Figure 11.32 
Four walls and 
dimensions

426 | CHAPTER 11 WORKING WITH PHASING, GROUPS, AND DESIGN OPTIONS  
Select the walls and dimensions in the view, and click the Create Group button on the con-
textual ribbon in the Create panel. Keep the default name, Group 1, for both Model Group and 
Attached Detail Group (Figure 11.33).
Figure 11.33 
Creating the model and 
attached detail group
Now select the group of walls and copy it to the side of your original group. You will notice 
that only the model-based group is copied, which is ﬁne for now (Figure 11.34).
Figure 11.34 
Copied model 
group
It is a simple process to associate the detail group to another instance of the model group. 
Select the group and then click the Attached Detail Groups button on the Group panel in the 
contextual ribbon, and you will see the dialog box shown in Figure 11.35. Select the check box 
for Group 1 from the list and click OK.

Now that you have created two identical groups, let’s add a door to one of the walls that belong 
to the group, as shown in Figure 11.37. To illustrate a point, do not add the door to the group—
just place it in one of the walls as you would with any nongrouped wall.

geometry and dimensions.

ment, shown in Figure 11.38, and the nongrouped elements will be grayed out. The screen 
overlay color alerts you that you are in Edit Group mode. The screen will appear with a 
yellow background in this mode. Here you will be able to add, remove, and attach other ele-
ments to your group.
Now add the door to the group by selecting the Add function from the Edit Group panel. 
When you add an element to the group, it will appear black in the Edit Group mode, letting you 
know it is available for selection. Once you select it and successfully add it to your group, it will 
turn gray with the rest of the group. If you had added a tag on placement, you would not be able 
to add it to the group because this is a model group and tags are 2D components. Now ﬁnish the

make the changes and/or additions, and then ﬁnish the group.

and make sure the new group is named Group 2 in the Project Browser.

in the Type Selector so you have one of each group type on the screen.

making it 13′-6″ square (4 m), as shown in Figure 11.41; then ﬁnish the group.

Groups have insertion points that you need to consider before you exchange one group for 
another. When you create a group, the insertion point is initially at the geometric center of all 
the elements in the group. The group’s origin is also identiﬁed by x- and y-coordinates.
Keep in mind that as you edit the group, the insertion point does not move until you delib-
erately relocate it. This can be seen in Figure 11.42; editing the geometry for Group 2 retains the 
same insertion point that was active when the group was initially created. Even though we have 
modiﬁed the group, the insertion point remains where it was originally when the group was cre-
ated. (When editing this group, the left wall was moved to the right and the top wall was moved 
down to achieve the dimensions.)

lower-left corner.

Excluding Elements within Groups
There will be occasions where everything in a group works great and it works throughout the 
project—except for that one particular case where a condition is slightly different. This is deftly 
handled by excluding individual elements from groups. The original group deﬁnitions remain 
intact, and schedules are aware of excluded elements. Figure 11.45 shows an example of this in 
practice. We have created another instance of Group 1; however, there is a column right in the 
middle of the door.
Figure 11.45 
A column location 
conﬂicts with the door 
in our sample group.
We do not want to destroy the integrity of the group and give up being able to quickly 
modify similar elements, but we also cannot advance the design with the column located where 
it is shown. To resolve this, hover the mouse pointer over the door within the group and then 
press the Tab key until the door is highlighted, right-click it, and select Create Similar from the 
context menu. This will allow you to place a new door in a better location. This door will not be 
part of the group. In Figure 11.46, the new door has been placed above the grouped door, and its 
swing direction has been ﬂipped.
Now you can exclude the door that conﬂicts with the column as an exception to the original 
group deﬁnition. This process can be a bit confusing at ﬁrst because you do not need to enter 
Group Edit mode to exclude members from groups. Simply hover the mouse pointer over the 
door and press the Tab key until the door is highlighted. Select the door, as shown in Figure 11.47.
Once the door in the group is selected, you will notice an icon pointing to the door. Clicking 
this icon will allow you to exclude the door as an exception to the group. The icon will change 
and show a red hash through it. This means the element is now excluded and will automatically 
be deleted when you deselect the group. The wall will heal itself as if the door were never there.

the group will reveal any hidden elements in the group that are excluded (Figure 11.48). Just tab 
through to select the hidden door to include the component back into the group.

Saving and Loading Groups
Just as you would not want your family components locked up inside a project ﬁle, there are 
good reasons to keep commonly used groups outside your project. You might even want to keep 
them in a folder just as you do your custom content so you can use them again on similar proj-
ects or as part of your ofﬁce’s library. You can do so by saving groups outside your projects.
Saving groups is a simple matter of right-clicking the group name in your Project Browser 
and selecting Save Group (Figure 11.49).
Figure 11.49 
Saving groups from the 
Project Browser
You will then be prompted to save the group as an RVT ﬁle. You can open this ﬁle as you 
would any other RVT ﬁle if you would like to modify it later and then reload the group into the 
project in order to update all the instances. To load an external group into a project, go to the 
Insert tab in the ribbon. On the Load From Library panel, choose Load As Group.
Be aware that when you load the group in a project, if the group name already exists, you 
will be given a warning. You can overwrite the existing group (by selecting Yes) or load with the 
option to rename the group that is being loaded (by selecting No). Or you can cancel the opera-
tion altogether (Figure 11.50).
Figure 11.50 
Loading groups with 
the same name

reloaded, overwriting the original group, but the exclusions remain intact.

Creating Groups from Links
Groups are also RVT ﬁles, and as such, they can be linked into the project environment. 
Although you cannot edit a link in place (as with a group), there are some excellent reasons why 
you might want to start a group as a link and then bind the link at a later time. Binding a linked 
project will convert it to a group. Groups and links can also exist within design options (more 
on design options later in this chapter). To follow this workﬂow, use these steps:
1. From the Insert tab in the ribbon, choose Link Revit from the Link panel (Figure 11.52).
Figure 11.52 
Use the Link Revit 
command to add 
groups as links.
2. Browse to the group you just exported and click Open.
After the link has been placed, you can copy it throughout your project as you would any 
other element in Revit. Keep in mind that all the functionality between groups and nongrouped 
elements will not behave the same in links as it does throughout the rest of your project. For 
example, in Figure 11.53, the upper-right collection of walls and furniture is a link, not a group. 
As a result, walls are not cleaning up between linked models and groups in the same way they 
are between groups and other walls in the project.

CREATING AND USING GROUPS | 435
Figure 11.53 
Walls do not join to 
linked models.
This graphic restriction may not be a concern during early stages of design, when links allow 
for a lot of rapid ﬂexibility. After you have resolved your design using linked models, you can 
bind them into the project environment by selecting each link in a view and clicking Bind Link 
from the contextual tab in the ribbon. When binding, make sure you select all instances of that 
link. Links bound will also revert any modiﬁed version to the original. This can be avoided by 
binding modiﬁed groups with other names.
Rather than explode the linked model into separate and unrelated elements, Revit converts 
the link to a group. Once this happens, walls easily join across groups, as shown in Figure 11.54.

Using Best Practices for Groups
So far, you have learned that groups can help you maintain consistency among repeated ele-
ments and will facilitate additional design iteration; however, there are some important excep-
tions that you will want to note. Nearly every time a problem crops up with groups, it is the 
result of ignoring one of the following best practices:
Do not put datum objects in your group.  Avoid putting datum objects (levels and grids) 
inside your group. You cannot manage the extents of the datum objects unless you are in Edit 
Group mode, which can create conﬂicts elsewhere in your project. Of course, you will have 
the option to not include the datum objects when you bind your link. Again, doing so does 
not necessarily create a technical hurdle, but it can create a lot of confusion. Situations arise 
where duplicate levels were deleted and sometimes those levels were hosting content in the 
project.
Do not nest groups.  In other words, avoid creating groups within other groups. Although 
nesting can save time in some situations when the design is preliminary and your team is 
trying to distribute content and design ideas quickly, you will likely ﬁnd a point of diminish-
ing returns as the design evolves. You cannot get to all the features and functionality of Revit 
when you are in Edit Group mode. And if you are nested deep into groups and trying to 
modify project properties, you will quickly get frustrated digging in, out, and across nested 
groups to go back and forth between your group and the project.
Group hosted elements and their hosts together.  Always keep your hosted elements 
and hosts together. For example, do not group doors and windows without the walls that 
are hosting them. If any of the windows in a group become unhosted from walls and then 
deleted, this will delete the respective windows in all other group instances—even if they are 
properly hosted.
Do not use attached relationships in groups.  The top constraints of walls are commonly 
attached to levels or other hosts such as ﬂoors and roofs, but these relationships should be 
avoided in groups. If you manipulate the datum or attached host and the relationship creates 
inconsistent conditions among the instances of the group, you will see a warning asking you 
to ﬁx the groups (Figure 11.55).
Figure 11.55 
Avoid attaching with 
groups.
Fixing the group really does not ﬁx the group. It actually explodes it or creates a new group 
that is no longer referenced to the ﬁrst group (Figure 11.56).

MAKING DESIGN OPTIONS FOR DESIGN ITERATION | 437
Figure 11.56 
Resolving attachments 
warning
Do not mirror groups.  Finally, and maybe most important, do not mirror groups. Instead, 
it is better to create left and right versions. Does mirroring work in concept? Yes. Does it work 
in the real world? Not really.
Think about it. You would love to be able to mirror that prototype coffee shop, right? Mirror 
the coffee shop—and all the equipment in the group—and now the baristas are foaming 
milk on the right rather than the left. This might look great in a rendering, but it does not 
make sense for the company that manufactures the espresso machines.
And now the display cases have power supplies on the wrong side. The cash register has 
keys on the wrong side. The desk in the manager’s ofﬁce now has drawers on the left and ﬁl-
ing cabinets on the right. To make matters worse, the sink in the bathroom now has hot water 
coming from the wrong faucet. Again, it makes all the conceptual sense in the world to be 
able to mirror a building—and a group. But trying to make it work can cost a lot of time and 
money. And this is just a coffee shop. If you think it is a good idea to mirror a hospital room 
or a surgical theater or some other mission-critical building or civil construct, well, it could 
end badly. Or you will have to work very, very late to resolve the issues.
If you would like to download the ﬁle that has been created during the examples, you can ﬁnd 
it in the Chapter 11 folder on the book’s web page; the ﬁle is called c11-Groups-Finished.rvt.
Making Design Options for Design Iteration
Revit software provides a unique set of tools for developing multiple design iterations in the 
conﬁnes of a single-model environment. You can use these tools to explore alternative designs 
without the need to save multiple independent versions of your model as you move in different 
directions. You are free to investigate multiple roof conﬁgurations or different entry canopies 
or to explore various furniture, ofﬁce layouts, and stairs—quite literally anything that can be 
modeled. This functionality also allows you to create views that show each option so multiple 
designs can be compared.
Let’s begin by establishing a fundamental understanding of the workﬂow for design options. 
First, you have a main model, which includes all the elements you have learned how to model so 
far in this book. The main model can be thought of as a backdrop or stage on which different 
options are displayed. Elements in the main model are always visible by default, whereas design 

438 | CHAPTER 11 WORKING WITH PHASING, GROUPS, AND DESIGN OPTIONS  
options come and go, appearing and disappearing depending on which design option you’re 
editing or viewing. Put another way, the main model includes everything else that is not in the 
design options.
You begin to explore design options by ﬁrst creating a named option set—for example, 
Canopy Options. Within the option set, you then deﬁne options, the ﬁrst of which is the pri-
mary option. Each option can be named to help you identify the intent, such as Glass Canopy 
and Steel Canopy. From here, you need to either select elements you have already modeled and 
add them to the appropriate design options or edit each option and create the elements with the 
Design Options tool active. Either way, the primary option in each option set will be displayed 
throughout your project by default. You can make as many options as you need—there is no 
limit.
The last part of conﬁguring design options is to create some additional views in which to 
compare the ideas. As soon as you start creating design options in a project, the Design Options 
tab is added to the Visibility/Graphic Overrides dialog box. In this interface, you can select a 
speciﬁc option to be displayed for any of the option sets in the project. You can then present 
them to a client, to the project architect, or to other stakeholders in the design process. At any 
time, you may set any other option as the primary option. This will affect any views that are 
displaying the default option.
When an option within a set is ﬁnalized, you can accept the primary design solution and add 
it back to the main model. Doing so deletes all elements in the other options within the option 
set and merges your accepted option back into the main model.
Creating Design Options
Let’s now explore the use of design options with a simple exercise. Download and open the ﬁle 
c11-DesignOptions-Start.rvt or c11-DesignOptions-Start-Metric.rvt from this book’s 
web page. The sample ﬁles have a simple layout of walls, as shown in Figure 11.57.
Figure 11.57

of walls to begin study-
ing design options
Starting in the Level 1 view, you are going to conﬁgure this simple space into a design option 
that divides the space vertically in one option and horizontally in the other. Follow these steps:
1. From the Manage tab in the ribbon, locate the Design Options panel (Figure 11.58) and 
then click the Design Options button.

3. Click New in the Option area of the dialog box to create an Option 2 option, as shown in 
Figure 11.59. Click Close to dismiss the dialog box.
Figure 11.59

ered the main model. You can start adding elements to one of the two options.

Note that when the elements are added to the option set, you immediately lose the ability 
to select them within the main model. This is because an option called Exclude Options in the 
status bar is checked by default. The purpose of this option is to support a workﬂow in which 
design options are explicitly edited. Otherwise, it is assumed you are working exclusively on 
other parts of the building design. Of course, you can disable this option at any time by dese-
lecting the check box in the status bar.
Editing Design Options
Selecting a design option to edit allows you to enter a special mode called Edit Option mode. 
In this mode, you can add elements you have already created in the main model or create them 
from within the option set. Visible elements in the Main Model that are not inside this option set 
turn light gray, indicating that they are not editable.
Entering Edit Option mode is quite easy. From the drop-down list in the Design Options 
toolbar or from the Design Options panel in the Manage tab, select the option you want to begin 
editing (Figure 11.62). In our example, we chose Option 2.
Figure 11.62 
Accessing Edit 
Option mode

MAKING DESIGN OPTIONS FOR DESIGN ITERATION | 441
Once you have entered Edit Option mode, you will notice that the wall you added to Option 1  
is not visible. Add one horizontal wall dividing the space, as shown in Figure 11.63. Note that 
anything else you add to the project while in Edit Option mode will be assigned to that design 
option. You can also modify or delete any elements in the selected option in this mode.
Figure 11.63 
Adding a wall in Edit 
Option mode
To exit Edit Option mode, return to the Design Options drop-down list and select Main 
Model. Remember that only the primary option will appear by default; therefore, when you 
ﬁnish adding the horizontal wall to Option 2 and you return to the main model, the horizontal 
wall will disappear and the vertical wall will reappear. In the next section, you will learn how 
to control the visibility of design options.
Viewing and Scheduling Design Options
You will notice that whenever you switch between Option 1 and Option 2, the view automati-
cally changes to show the option that you have selected. Initiating design options automatically 
creates a new tab in the Visibility/Graphic Overrides dialog box. By default, a design option’s 
display shows as <Automatic> (Figure 11.64). This means the Primary design option (in this 
case, Option 1) will be shown in the view.
Figure 11.64 
Te Design Options 
tab displays 
<Automatic>.
The Design Options tab is available for any view, even for schedules. Selecting the Visibility/
Graphic settings in the view properties of a schedule ﬁlters the schedule according to the 
desired design option.
If you want to specify or lock a view to a particular design option, open the Visibility/
Graphic Overrides dialog box and select the Design Options tab. From the drop-down list, 
change the setting from <Automatic> to one of the design options (Figure 11.65).

442 | CHAPTER 11 WORKING WITH PHASING, GROUPS, AND DESIGN OPTIONS  
Figure 11.65 
Locking the view to a 
design option
For working views, it is ﬁne to leave the view properties set to <Automatic> so that the 
view switches to actively show the primary design option; however, using the Visibility/
Graphic settings can be particularly useful for views that are being placed on sheets. To 
show multiple design options on one sheet, simply duplicate any relevant views and use the 
Visibility/Graphic settings to set a speciﬁc design option for each view. One of the compelling 
visualization techniques using this feature is perspective. You can quickly and easily show a 
variety of design options all from the same vantage point within the model by simply creat-
ing a perspective view, duplicating it, and setting the relevant design option in the Visibility/
Graphic settings. Creating a system for naming options and option sets will help you organize 
them effectively.
Removing Design Options and Option Sets
As your project progresses, it may become necessary to delete an option set, accept the pri-
mary design option, or delete a single design option. Although some of these methods might 
yield similar outcomes, there are important differences. Remember that you can create an 
unlimited number of option sets and any number of individual options within each set. 
Maintaining too many design options may have adverse performance effects on your project 
ﬁle, so you should be conscious of the status of all design options. As always, each option set 
should be named appropriately so that your project team can understand the intended use of 
each study.
Accepting the Primary Design Option
The most common outcome of a design option study is to accept one option and delete the 
remaining ones. The Design Option tools are built to support this workﬂow quite effectively.
To accept the primary design option, open the Design Options dialog box from the 
Manage tab or the status bar. Select the associated option set from the list. Make sure the 
option you want to keep is the primary option. If it is not, select that option; then click the 
Make Primary button. Once that is complete, click the Accept Primary button, as shown in 
Figure 11.66.
When you accept the primary option in an option set, the geometry associated with the 
primary option is integrated into the main model. Any geometry on other options within the 
selected option set is deleted.
You will proceed through a series of warnings and conﬁrmations before completing the 
process. If any views are speciﬁcally assigned to display the options being deleted, you will 
have the option to delete or retain such views (Figure 11.67). This is a good way to keep your 
project ﬁle clean and free from extraneous views related to the rapid iteration process of 
design options.

Preserving Your Design Iterations
In our experience, we have heard many stories about vast amounts of eﬀort that have been wiped 
out when various actions are taken in a Revit model, usually for the sake of improving performance. 
One classic scenario is when several design options are created and only one is moved forward after 
certain project milestones. If you use the Design Options tool, be sure to create an archive copy 
of your project model before you activate potentially destructive commands such as accepting the 
primary design option or deleting an option set.

444 | CHAPTER 11 WORKING WITH PHASING, GROUPS, AND DESIGN OPTIONS  
Deleting an Option Set
Do not confuse the ability to completely delete an option set with the ability to accept the pri-
mary option and delete all other options within the set. If you delete an option set, all options 
within the set are deleted. This workﬂow is less common because you usually study options for 
some element of your design that will need to be included in one form or another. Sometimes 
you may just need to study a potential addition to the scope of your project and it does not get 
accepted. This is where it is useful to completely delete an option set.
To delete an option set, return to the Design Options dialog box and select an option set. 
Click the Delete button in the Option Set area, as shown in Figure 11.68. As in the previous exer-
cise, you will be prompted with a series of warnings and conﬁrmations because of the content 
you are about to permanently delete from your project.
Figure 11.68 
Deleting an option set
Deleting an Individual Option
Another common workﬂow in the iteration of design is to delete just one of the options within 
an option set. This may occur for various reasons, but let’s say you did not want to continue 
exploring the option for all enclosed ofﬁces in the furniture layout for the ﬁrst ﬂoor of your  
project. In Figure 11.69, we have the Design Options dialog box open and the All Enclosed 
option selected within the 1st Floor Furniture option set. From here, you would click the 
Delete button in the Option area, as shown in the ﬁgure.
You cannot delete the primary option in an option set. Some other option must be assigned 
as the primary option before you can delete the original primary option. To make an option 
the primary option, open the Design Options dialog box, select an option, and click the Make 
Primary button.
