 Chapter  22 
 Design Analysis   
 In this chapter, we will take a further look at the Autodesk ® Revit ® conceptual design tools 
and how you can leverage them for sustainable design analysis. We’ll also explore a few other 
tools, some of which use building information modeling (BIM) geometry to support design 
analysis. 
 Most building design starts with some simple concepts and forms. Will the building be tall or 
long? Curved or rectilinear? How will those shapes affect sustainable design concepts like solar 
gain, daylighting, and energy consumption? To perform these kinds of analyses and explore the 
initial ideas for building form in Revit, we use masses. In the previous chapter, we discussed 
how to create several kinds of massing. In this chapter, we’ll explore a different type of mass 
called a  conceptual mass and use that to generate sustainable design analysis. 
 In this chapter, you’ll learn to 
 
◆
Embrace energy analysis concepts 
 
◆
 Analyze your model for energy performance 
 
◆
Analyze your model for daylighting performance 
 Analyzing for Sustainability 
 Environmentally thoughtful design strategies have been around for millennia, but the practice 
of sustainable design with quantiﬁ able metrics has seen substantial growth in the past decade. 
Sustainable design practices can help address many issues, among them energy use, access 
to natural daylight, human health and productivity, and resource conservation. One of the 
principal goals of sustainable design is to reduce a building’s overall resource use. This can be 
measured in the building’s carbon footprint ( www.architecture2030.org ) or the net amount of 
carbon dioxide emitted by a building through its energy use. 
 Before we delve into discussing any speciﬁ c workﬂ ows involving BIM and sustainable design 
analysis, it’s important to recognize that many concepts are both interdependent and cumula-
tive. The more sustainable methods you can incorporate into a project, the “greener” the project 
becomes. 
 Take the example of building orientation, glazing, and daylighting. Designing your building 
in the optimal orientation, using the right glass in the correct amount and location, and inte-
grating sunshading into the project to optimize the use of natural light all build on each other. 
Using these three strategies together makes a building operate more efﬁ ciently while allowing 
Mastering Autodesk® Revit® 2018 
By Lance Kirby, Eddy Krygiel and Marcus Kim 
Copyright © 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc., Indianapolis, Indiana 

904 | CHAPTER 22 DESIGN ANALYSIS 
occupants access to plenty of natural light. The amount of usable daylight you might capture 
will be greatly reduced with the application of highly reﬂective glass or if the building’s orienta-
tion is inappropriate for the geography. The appropriateness and beneﬁts of any of these indi-
vidual strategies depend on building type and climate.
Revit software has similar characteristics. Because it is a parametric modeler, all the parts are 
interrelated. Understanding and capitalizing on these relationships typically takes numerous 
iterations that span multiple projects. Optimizing the integrated strategies and technologies for 
a high-performance design requires an understanding of how they work together to deliver the 
best potential. That is where Revit comes in—allowing the ability to iterate and analyze faster 
than in a more traditional process. The process is built on the following methodology for reduc-
ing the energy consumption of buildings:
 
◆
Understand climate
 
◆
Reduce loads
 
◆
Use free energy
 
◆
Use efﬁcient systems
Understanding Energy Modeling
Understanding a building’s energy needs is paramount to helping the project become more 
sustainable and reducing costs throughout the building lifecycle. According to the U.S. Energy 
Information Administration (www.eia.doe.gov), as of March 2015 buildings in the United States 
account for 30 percent of the world’s energy consumption and 60 percent of the world’s electric-
ity use, making the United States the primary consumer of energy in the world (Figure 22.1).
Figure 22.1 
Energy use in the 
United States
U.S. Electrical Energy Consumption
Transportation
1%
Buildings
76%
Industry
23%
Within the United States, buildings consume nearly half (47 percent) of all energy produced 
in the United States and are responsible for more than 44 percent of CO2 emissions in the nation 
per year, exceeding emissions in the transportation sector (34 percent) and industrial sector  
(21 percent). (See architecture2030.org/about.) Architecture 2030 seeks to achieve a dramatic 
reduction in energy consumption and CO2 emissions by changing the way that buildings and 
communities are planned, designed, and built.
The Architecture 2030 Challenge was established in recognition of the signiﬁcant role that 
buildings play in the climate change crisis. Architecture 2030 established the 2030 Challenge, 
asking the global AEC community to adopt a series of CO2 emissions reduction targets and sus-
tainable building design strategies to ensure that all new buildings, developments, and renova-
tions are carbon-neutral by 2030.

ANALYZING FOR SUSTAINABILITY | 905
It is important to distinguish carbon-neutral from net-zero energy buildings. Net-zero build-
ings must produce as much energy onsite as the building consumes. In contrast, carbon-neutral 
buildings do not use fossil fuels or emit greenhouse gases. While this may sound impossible, 
there are intelligent and realistic design options to achieve sustainability targets, including 
optimizing building orientation, passive heating and cooling, and daylighting. These low-cost/
no-cost methods in combination with energy-efﬁcient technologies such as high-efﬁciency 
mechanical equipment, onsite renewable energy generation, and offsite renewable energy or 
credits can contribute to carbon-neutrality goals.
The design of new buildings and major renovations are targeted to meet a fossil fuel and 
energy performance standard of 70 percent below the regional average for the building type 
(derived from Commercial Buildings Energy Consumption Survey [CBECS]). The fossil fuel 
reduction standard is then increased to 80 percent in 2020, 90 percent in 2025, and an ultimate 
target of carbon-neutral buildings by 2030.
The 2030 Challenge has been embraced by the AIA in the form of the AIA 2030 Commitment. 
Global architecture ﬁrms (nearly 400) have signed on to the commitment. A cornerstone of the 
commitment is energy modeling, which the AIA describes as playing a critical role in improving 
building design and building performance (as stated in the AIA 2014 progress report). Leading 
architecture ﬁrms recognize that in designing projects that meet the 2030 targets, they are providing 
their clients with the highest-quality, top-performing buildings at minimal or zero additional cost.
Using Revit for Energy Simulations
Energy simulation is key to meeting the 2030 Challenge and critical sustainable building design. 
Historically, one of the biggest barriers to successful discovery and implementation of sustainable 
design measures for buildings is the difﬁculty of getting informative energy simulation results 
early in the design process quickly and cheaply. A common approach to improving models for 
energy simulation has been to increase the precision of model inputs, requiring considerable effort 
and time. Even after signiﬁcant effort, the results are often still inaccurate when compared to real-
world buildings because errors due to uncertainties and operational variations are still present.
Revit now addresses these challenges with rapid energy simulation leveraging  
EnergyPlus and DOE 2 energy analysis engines with results presented in Autodesk Insight 
(insight360.autodesk.com).
The energy needs of a building depend on a number of issues that are not simply related to 
leaving the lights on in a room that you are no longer using, turning down the heat, or increasing 
the air-conditioning. Many of the components and systems within a building affect its energy 
use. For instance, if you increase the size of the windows on the south facade, you allow in more 
natural light and lower your need for electric lighting. However, without proper sunshading, you 
are also letting in additional solar heat gain, so those larger windows are increasing your need 
for air-conditioning and potentially negating the energy savings from reduced lighting.
In exploring the use of energy in a building, you must consider all energy-related issues, 
which is a good reason to use energy-simulation tools. These computer-based models use cli-
mate data coupled with building loads, such as the following:
 
◆
The heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) system
 
◆
Solar heat gain
 
◆
The number of occupants and their activity levels
 
◆
Sunshading devices
 
◆
Daylight dimming
 
◆
Lighting levels

906 | CHAPTER 22 DESIGN ANALYSIS 
The energy model combines these factors to predict the building’s energy demands to help 
size the building’s HVAC system. It also combines the parameters of other components properly 
so you are not using a system larger than what you need, and you can understand the impact of 
your design on the environment. By keeping the energy model updated with the current design, 
you can begin to grasp how building massing, building envelopes, window locations, building 
orientation, and other parameters affect energy demands.
There are four ways you can use Revit Architecture software for energy analysis: concep-
tual massing, schematic/facade design, detailed modeling, or exporting to other applications 
(Figure 22.2). Let’s explore each of these workﬂows in a bit more detail.
Figure 22.2 
Ways of using Revit 
Architecture software 
for energy analysis
Conceptual/Massing Analysis  Conceptual or massing analysis allows you to analyze 
the energy consumption of the model directly within Revit. Using this workﬂow, you can 
analyze mass forms directly in the model and view energy simulation results within Insight 
(http://insight.autodesk.com). This is ideal for the following use cases:
 
◆
Early targeting and assessing feasibility, including feasibility of client goals and 
expectations
 
◆
Guiding early-stage architectural decisions such as geometry, orientation, window-to-wall 
ratio, shading, and materials to reduce energy consumption
 
◆
Meeting the requirements for the AIA 2030 Design Data Exchange (DDx) submittal, which 
is one of the steps to meeting the 2030 Challenge
 
◆
Exporting your model to gbXML, DOE2, or EnergyPlus formats for additional analysis
Schematic/Facade Design  By using a simple massing model, you can quickly apply curtain 
wall systems to mass faces using the Curtain System tool on the Model By Face panel of the 
Massing & Site tab. This workﬂow works best with massing objects rather than more reﬁned 
model data as it allows quick iterations of the building facade. This workﬂow is valuable in 
any of the previously mentioned cases, but would also include the following:
 
◆
Model content has more accurate settings for walls and exterior shading.
 
◆
It allows you to specify space and material thermal properties providing additional detail 
in the analysis.
Detailed Models  A detailed Revit model refers to the type of model you would have closer 
to the end of the construction documentation process. These models are richer in speciﬁc 

USING THE CONCEPTUAL ENERGY ANALYSIS TOOL | 907
materiality and other features that would change energy consumption. They also allow for 
the isolation of elements that are used in the creation of the energy model and resolution of 
missing elements or large “gaps” in the design. For instance, if a section of the building has 
unresolved design elements, you can still create a meaningful analysis by isolating that por-
tion of the building. The beneﬁts to this workﬂow include those listed earlier and the speciﬁ-
cation of space and material thermal properties.
Export  This workﬂow requires exporting a more detailed model to another application 
using the gbXML format (a standardized XML schema used for sustainable design analysis). 
Additional export options include INP and IDF for DOE 2 and EnergyPlus.
Numerous experiments with energy analysis throughout all the stages of model development 
reveal consistency in energy simulation results. Note that in Figure 22.3, the energy cost ranges 
have little variation from conceptual mass to more detailed models. Our point is that massing 
models with Insight is fast, simple, valuable, and worth exploring early in building design to 
guide design decisions, with continuous optimization as design progresses.
Figure 22.3 
Energy cost ranges in 
diﬀerent models
Regardless of your choice of analysis workﬂow, the ﬁrst step is to have accurate location and 
true north settings for your model. Without them, it is impossible to understand the localized 
energy performance. Once you have those established, you can approach energy analysis with 
conﬁdence. Let’s take a look at the process for generating a conceptual energy analysis.
Using the Conceptual Energy Analysis Tool
A conceptual energy analysis (CEA) tool has been part of the Revit software since 2009. This tool 
created a link to the online analysis service known as the Autodesk® Green Building Studio® 
web service. These tools have since evolved into Autodesk Insight, which leverages the DOE2 

908 | CHAPTER 22 DESIGN ANALYSIS 
and EnergyPlus simulation engines, providing millions of parametric simulations with results 
presented in interactive dashboards. The energy analysis results are generated quickly and pro-
vide the following:
 
◆
Estimate of energy use intensity (EUI) in kBtu/sf/year or kWh/m2/yr
 
◆
Energy operational cost estimate
 
◆
Benchmarking against Architecture 2030 and ASHRAE 90.1
 
◆
Interactive key performance indicators or building factors, rank-ordered by their relative 
inﬂuence on energy use and costs
 
◆
Ability to manipulate key performance factors and compare design options to drive 
toward desired energy outcomes
 
◆
Ability to report directly into the Architecture 2030 DDx, directly from Insight  
(www.aia.org/pages/5041-aia-2030-design-data-exchange-ddx)
In the following exercise, you will load a conceptual mass into a template project to run 
a series of energy analyses. There are ﬁve basic tools for conﬁguration, analysis, and com-
parison of results on the Analyze tab of the ribbon for both building elements and masses 
(Figure 22.4).

Before you can run an analysis for either building elements or massing, you need to do a bit of 
conﬁguration to give your analysis engine some parameters. You’re going to use a building that

ofﬁce space. You can download the ﬁle from the book’s companion web site: www.sybex.com/
go/masteringrevit2018. The model is c22-Analysis-Start.rvt.

1. Activate the Default 3D view, and in the view control bar, set Visual Style to Shaded. Turn

3. Next, on the Analyze tab, click Energy Settings. Energy settings drive the behavior of the 
energy model you will create and allow optional use of additional properties if speciﬁed, 
including materials and thermal spaces. Figure 22.7 shows the Energy Settings dialog

You’ll notice a lot of options in the Energy Settings dialog box—some of them quite complex.
4. In the Energy Settings dialog box, change the following values:
Mode  Revit offers three modes for creating the energy model. For all cases, you should 
use the mode Use Conceptual Masses and Building Elements because it includes more 
accurate thermal zoning capabilities and it will use the building type to create the 2030 
benchmark in Insight. Note that this mode supports masses, building elements, or com-
binations. A reason to not use this mode would be if you wanted to isolate certain geom-
etries from other components.
Ground Plane  This should be set to Level 1 so that the model assumes contact with the 
group for heat transfer.
The rest of the settings we are going to leave as they are, but let’s review them so you under-
stand their impact to the conceptual model.

USING THE CONCEPTUAL ENERGY ANALYSIS TOOL | 911
Project Phase  This is the phase the analysis will be run against. Keep the default set-
ting of New Construction, but if you had multiple phases to your project, you could 
change how the analysis is run here. It is important to note that if a later project phase 
is selected, properties assigned to a later building phase are omitted from the energy 
analysis.
Analytical Space Resolution and Analytical Surface Resolution  These numbers dic-
tate the tolerances for Revit to resolve the spaces and surfaces within the model. For our 
uses, keep the default values (1′ 6″ and 1/-0″, respectively).
Perimeter Zone Depth and Perimeter Zone Division  When this setting is enabled (the 
default), zones are automatically deﬁned around the perimeter of the massing form. If 
you prefer to create your own zones, disable this setting and set the Core Offset value to 0. 
Then create more detailed mass forms and use the Cut Geometry tool to combine over-
lapping forms.
Other Options  Choose the Edit button and you’ll see the Advanced Energy Settings 
dialog box (Figure 22.8). As the dialog box suggests, these are more advanced settings 
for the energy performance and building systems. You don’t have to manipulate many of 
these settings because you can vary them in Insight, but let’s walk through them here so 
you can see what’s available from this dialog box.
Figure 22.8

Settings dialog box
Target Percentage Glazing  This value sets the assumed amount of glazing as a 
percentage of the overall wall area.
Target Sill Height  This is the height of the sill for glazing to begin on each ﬂoor.

912 | CHAPTER 22 DESIGN ANALYSIS 
Glazing Is Shaded  Select this check box if you intend to design sunshading for the 
glazing. This does not differentiate by building orientation, so if you check the box, 
conceptual shading elements will be added to the glazing assumptions on all sides.
Shade Depth  When the Glazing Is Shaded option is checked, you can assign a 
depth to any assumed sunshading.
Target Percentage Skylights  Like Target Percentage Glazing, this value assumes an 
amount of skylighting for your model.
Skylight Width & Depth  This value sets the size for skylights if you are using them.
Building Type  This value sets the type of building use. By default, it is set to Ofﬁce, 
but there are many different building uses. The building use will help dictate the 
type of load on the building, assumed number of occupants, and so on.
Building Operation Schedule  How often will your building be occupied? Will 
it have people in it 24/7, or will it be operational only during ofﬁce hours? This can 
have a large impact on your heating and cooling cycles.
HVAC System  Here you can set a conceptual HVAC system. That could be a 
four-pipe system, underﬂoor air distribution, or a variety of other HVAC system 
types.
Outdoor Air Information  If you know how many air exchanges you’ll be required 
to produce per hour, you can set that value here.
Export Category  Your option here is either Rooms or Spaces. If you’re working 
from an architectural model, chances are you’re using Rooms. If this were an MEP 
model or you were linking in information from an MEP consultant, you’d want to use 
Spaces. For our exercise, leave it set to Rooms.

After you have established some baseline settings and assumptions for an energy analysis, it’s

previous section to your model. This process can take a bit of time. As a warning, Revit will 
provide you with a dialog box noting that it will not be accessible during the computation time 
(Figure 22.11). Click Create The Energy Analytical Model to continue.

The time required for analysis depends on model size, model complexity, and the simula-

When you receive the e-mail stating that your analysis is ready for review, you can access it 
one of two ways. You can click the Optimize button within Revit or follow the e-mailed link to 
your Insight simulation project. Using either option will open the Insight 360 tool (Figure 22.15) 
showing your energy model results.

the run has not been associated with a project. Before you review the analysis, let’s ﬁrst create 
a project. Choose Insights from the menu along the top of the dialog box. This will take you to 
the main Insight 360 screen and allow you to create a project. Click the + Create Insight button, 
select the model you just ran from the list, and click Done. This will effectively put that model 
run into a folder within Insight 360.

Creating a Realistic Baseline
The Insight default run includes the full range of options across all energy factors, including the 
BIM settings that were assigned in the Revit model or are assumed based on building type. It is 
prudent to quickly create a more realistic baseline for analysis based on your general knowledge 
of the building, industry standards, building type, typical systems, regional building practices, 
or other guidance. In this exercise, you will create a more reﬁned baseline scenario that reduces 
the uncertainties initially introduced by the Insight engine because of minimal data input and 
broad assumptions:
1. Save the original (default) Insight and add an alternate scenario by selecting the Add 
Scenario icon at the top-right corner of the Insight page (Figure 22.21). This will pull a 
panel into the dialog box from the left of the screen.

scenario Baseline from Revit and press Enter to save the scenario name. We’re going to 
modify some of the assumptions to better reﬁne the analysis.

lower-performing HVAC and other factors that are moderate in performance. To modify

Using Architecture 2030
Architecture 2030 is a nonproﬁt organization established in response to the climate change cri-
sis by architect Edward Mazria in 2002. Architecture 2030’s mission is to rapidly transform the 
global built environment from the major contributor of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to a 
central part of the solution to the climate crisis. More than 350 ﬁrms are currently participating 
in the AIA 2030 Commitment. If you are one of these ﬁrms or are interested in modeling to this 
performance metric, you need to report your project data, which has historically been cumber-
some. Insight automates the data entry process and streamlines AIA 2030 reporting.
In the following steps, you’ll explore how to take your current analysis and use it for 
Architecture 2030:
1. First, you need to enable the Architecture 2030 service. This service is called AIA DDx 
and is available as an Insight service. Choose your proﬁle picture in the Insight dialog 
box and then choose Services from the drop-down list (Figure 22.29). Choose the AIA 
DDx slider to enable the service.
Figure 22.29 
Enabling AIA DDx
2. To use the service, you or your ﬁrm will need to be registered participants. You can reg-
ister for the program at http://architecture2030.org/2030_challenges/adopt_the_
challenge. Registration will provide you with an API key and a client key that you can 
enter into the Insight dialog box (Figure 22.30).
Figure 22.30 
Registering your proj-
ect with AIA 2030

USING THE CONCEPTUAL ENERGY ANALYSIS TOOL | 927
3. After you’ve generated an Insight from Revit and identiﬁed the key factors that are driv-
ing energy cost and performance, select Report to AIA DDx from the options menu for 
the model (Figure 22.31).
Figure 22.31

white ﬁelds can be edited. Finally, click Send to provide the project information to the 
AIA DDx (Figure 22.32).

Making More Informed Decisions
We have seen so many projects in which design forms were arbitrarily created and presented to 
clients—only to have them choose the option that looked the most compelling. Cost of construc-
tion may come into play for a more complex design against a simpler solution. But what about how 
each of the design solutions will perform after construction?
Using the energy analysis tools has allowed our teams not only to present various design ideas to 
clients but to accompany the forms with performance characteristics as well. One design may cost 
more to construct, but it is projected to perform better in terms of heating loads in the winter. We 
frequently use selected graphs and comparisons from the Insight reports in our presentations to 
clients. Tis enhanced information increases client conﬁdence in making key decisions when they 
are most appropriate to drive value in the design and construction process.
Understanding Lighting Analysis
The Light Analysis Revit (LA/R) capabilities within the Insight tool leverage the Autodesk ren-
dering cloud service to understand the daylighting availability for your building design. Using 
natural daylight to light a building space can signiﬁcantly impact your energy performance 
by reducing the need for artiﬁcial lighting. Lighting analysis in Revit is quick and accurate. 
Additionally, it supports automated scheduling to study common analysis types. Supported 
analysis types include the following:
 
◆
Illuminance Analysis
 
◆
Daylight Autonomy (sDA preview)
 
◆
LEED 2009 IEQc8 opt1
 
◆
LEED v4 EQc7 opt1
 
◆
LEED v4 EQc7 opt2
 
◆
Solar Access
The Revit LA/R service does not require that architects understand complicated concepts, 
such as Perez versus CIE’s sky models or direct normal incident versus direct horizontal radia-
tion. It is easy to get started with lighting analysis for the whole building or just speciﬁc areas.
To get started, let’s dive right into getting the analysis set up and running. To begin, you’ll 
need to make sure your version of Revit is up to date. This will include making sure the 
Lighting and Solar Analysis for Revit tool is loaded. You can ﬁnd this tool in the Autodesk 
Desktop App (Figure 22.33).
Figure 22.33 
Loading the 
daylighting tool

UNDERSTANDING LIGHTING ANALYSIS | 929
You’re going to use the same model you’ve been using for the energy analysis. You can down-
load the model, c22_Analysis_Start-Lighting.rvt, from the book’s companion website. Here 
are some basic assumptions:
 
◆
You’ve given the building a location.
 
◆
You’ve provided proper orientation (for example, the north side of the building actually 
faces north). If not, use the Rotate True North tool on the Manage tab to adjust the building 
direction.
 
◆
You are still logged into A360 from the previous exercise. You will need to be logged into 
your account to run the analysis.
With those assumptions taken care of, there is one other setting we need to address to set up 
the building for a realistic daylighting study. A key component to daylighting inside of a build-
ing is the glazing. If light isn’t passing through the glass properly, you’re not going to get accu-
rate daylighting results. You need to make sure you set the right materials, both for the glass 
(light transmittance) and for the interior surfaces (light reﬂectivity).
All of your elements within the model—or at least within the space to be analyzed—should 
have materials deﬁned. Even generic elements such as generic walls need to be deﬁned. Let’s 
look at some of these materials in more detail.
One common material will be paint (Figure 22.34). Here, we have applied paint as the ﬁnish 
type, called Cool White, to describe the ﬁnish type for Gypsum Wall Board, one of our most 
common building materials. As you can see on the Appearance tab, you have the ability to 
change some of the properties of the paint. You can alter the ﬁnish (ﬂat, eggshell, semi-gloss, 
gloss, and so on) and the application, which is how the paint is applied to the wall (rolled, 
sprayed, and so on). Each of these will affect the reﬂectance of the paint in a different way. If you 
don’t know the exact ﬁnish, it’s OK to use one as an estimate for now.
Figure 22.34 
Setting materiality for 
walls

930 | CHAPTER 22 DESIGN ANALYSIS 
In any case, four material properties should be set for all the materials you have in your 
building. Having these as accurate as possible will help establish the most accurate lighting lev-
els within the space. If you don’t know what color or material type to use, some generic sugges-
tions later in this chapter will help establish some median lighting conditions.
Color  The color of the glazing will partially determine light transmittance. Set your glazing 
color to reﬂect the color you will have in your design. The software supplies several common 
glazing colors.
Reﬂectance  As with different colors, reﬂectance will also help determine how much light 
you will get inside a space. You will see that if you use the Replace feature at the top to select 
one of the preset glazing colors, it will also give you a default value for reﬂectance.
Transmittance  Transmittance measures the amount of light that will come through the 
glass. Reﬂective glazing or smoked glass will have a lower transmittance than clear glazing.
Sheets Of Glass  The number of sheets of glass will determine how the light will be 
refracted as it moves from outside the building to the inside. Typically, in a Revit window 
family, you model glass as a 1″ (25 mm) single pane for ease of modeling. Modifying the 
number of panes in this location will allow you to keep your modeling simpliﬁed but still 
maintain a level of accuracy in the daylighting analysis.
Another material you should review is Glass. Getting the proper glazing settings will deter-
mine how much daylight you are getting inside the space. Select Glass or Glass, Clear Glazing 
from the material list and choose the Appearance tab to see the options shown in Figure 22.35. 
There are a few critical settings for glazing: Color, Reﬂectance, and Sheets Of Glass. These are 
similar to the other material properties previously discussed.
Figure 22.35 
Settings for glazing

UNDERSTANDING LIGHTING ANALYSIS | 931
Depending on the stage of design you are in, you might not know what your ﬁnal material 
is, but you want to create some default material types so you can perform some preliminary 
lighting analysis. When in doubt, here are some default reﬂectance values you can apply to the 
generic materials:
 
◆
Floors: 20 percent reﬂectance
 
◆
Walls: 50 percent reﬂectance
 
◆
Ceilings: 85 percent reﬂectance

open dialog boxes.

dialog box to move to the ﬁrst step. You are given the option to run a new analysis type 
or recall previously saved results. Since you haven’t done an analysis yet, choose Select 
Run New Analysis and then click Go.
2. Next, the Lighting Analysis In the Cloud dialog box opens (Figure 22.36) and allows you 
to control the study settings.
Figure 22.36

THE BOTTOM LINE | 935
Te Bottom Line
Embrace energy analysis concepts.  Understanding the concepts behind sustainable design 
is an important part of being able to perform analysis within the Revit model and a critical 
factor in today’s design environment.
Master It  What are four key methods for a holistic sustainable design?
Analyze your model for energy performance.  Being able to predict a building’s energy 
performance is a necessary part of designing sustainably. Although Revit doesn’t have an 
energy-modeling application built into it, it does have interoperability with many applica-
tions that have that functionality.
Master It  Explain the steps you need to take to get a Revit model ready for energy 
analysis.
Analyze your model for daylighting performance.  Understanding the concepts behind 
daylighting analysis is an important part of sustainable design. It is more than just under-
standing how light comes into a space; it is also understanding how the exterior and interior 
building design can help to bring light deeper into a building and provide a better quality of 
lighting overall.
Master It  What are the four primary items to consider when you’re looking to perform 
accurate daylighting analysis?

 Appendix A
T e Bottom Line  
 Each of The Bottom Line sections in the chapters suggest exercises to deepen skills and under-
standing. Sometimes there is only one possible solution, but often you are encouraged to use 
your skills and creativity to create something that builds on what you know and lets you 
explore one of many possible solutions. 
 Chapter  1 : Understanding the Principles of BIM 
Focus your investment in BIM.  Since using Revit software is a change in workﬂ ow, it is 
also important to understand the change in stafﬁ ng and who is needed to perform what roles 
on a project. 
Master It  What are the three primary roles in a Revit project, and what are the respon-
sibilities of those roles? 
Solution  Every successful Revit project will need three roles. These roles do not need 
to be individual people; one person can assume all three roles at any point in the project. 
The roles are architect, modeler, and drafter. These roles are responsible for understand-
ing and articulating the design, creating model content, and laying out and annotating 
the documentation, respectively. 
Understand a BIM workﬂ ow.  Understand how projects are completed in BIM and how the 
use of Revit software on a project can change how information within a project is created. 
Master It  Explain one of the primary differences between a more traditional 2D CAD-
based workﬂ ow and producing documents using Revit. 
Solution  In a 2D CAD-based workﬂ ow, documents are created by team members by 
creating plans, sections, elevations, and details, all as separate drawings, and then manu-
ally coordinating that content for the project set. In a BIM or Revit workﬂ ow, the plans, 
sections, elevations, and perspectives are a by-product of creating the virtual building 
model and are coordinated through updates made to the model itself. 
Leverage BIM processes.  Understanding the level of risk your ﬁ rm is willing to take in 
new technologies will help you establish goals for your future use of BIM. 
Master It  Using the three areas of ﬁ rm integration (visualization, analysis, and strat-
egy), deﬁ ne how those areas overlap for your ﬁ rm or project. 
Solution  Remember, there is no wrong answer in mapping a path forward for your ﬁ rm 
or project. The important thing is to identify which areas are critical to the workﬂ ow of 
your ﬁ rm to help you focus your future efforts.

Chapter 2: Exploring the UI and Organizing Projects
Understand the user interface.  In addition to understanding how your project is orga-
nized, to use the Revit software well, you must understand how the UI is organized. Once 
you grasp both of these concepts, you will be ready to move ahead.
Master It  The “big” areas of the UI are the ribbon, the Properties palette, the Project 
Browser, and the drawing area. How do these areas work together, and what tabs corre-
spond to an iterative design process?
Solution  The Architecture tab is where you’ll turn in your early design process because it 
contains datum objects, system families, component families, and spaces. As the design de-
velops, you’ll establish your views from the View tab. When you start to get into documen-
tation, you’ll work from the Annotate tab. Having panels from the Modify tab pulled off 
and close at hand will keep you from having to go between one contextual tab and another.
Understand project organization.  The compelling advantage of being able to design, docu-
ment, and manage your project across multiple disciplines—the architectural, structural, and 
mechanical disciplines—is something that you can do in Revit, and understanding project 
workﬂow is key to getting off on the right foot.
Master It  Thinking back to the Revit organizational chart shown in Figure 2.22 (and 
here in Figure A.1), what are the main components of a Revit project, and how can you 
apply them to your design process? How do these categories directly affect your  
design workﬂow?
Solution  The top-level categories of a Revit project are datum, content, views, and man-
agement. They correspond to the design process of maintaining relationships, repetition, 
representations, and restrictions. Keep these corollaries in mind as you move sequentially 
from schematic design, design development, construction documentation, and construc-
tion management.
Chapter 3: Te Basics of the Toolbox
Select, modify, and replace elements.  Many fundamental interactions are supported by 
Revit software to select just what you need and to modify elements efﬁciently.
Master It  How can you quickly select only the door tags in a plan view and switch 
them to another type?
Solution  First, window-select the entire plan. Then, using the Filter tool in the Modify 
tab of the ribbon, select only the Door Tags category, close the Filter dialog box, and 
change the type in the Properties palette.
Edit elements interactively.  The editing tools in Revit are similar to those found in other 
CAD and BIM software programs. Tools such as Move, Copy, and Trim are available on the 
Modify tab of the ribbon.
Master It  How do you create a parametric repetition of an element?
Solution  Select an element and activate the Array tool from the Modify tab of the rib-
bon. Specify a linear array with the Group And Associate option, and choose either Move 
To 2nd for speciﬁc element spacing or Move To Last for consistent overall length with 
varied element spacing.
